The cancer treatment has experienced three revolutions.
It started with more than 70 years ago,
the development of cytotoxic drugs
that work by killing the fastest growing cells.
However, this type of therapy
cannot kill the last cancer cell without killing the person
because cancer cells are not the fastest growing cells
in our body.
The second revolution was marked
by the development of target therapies
that inhibit pathways that cancer cells are addicted to.
However, cancer cells can always evolve
to be addicted to something else.
So drug resistance can averagely occur.
The third revolution is marked by the development
of immunotherapy and perhaps it's best publicized
by this example.
This is president Jimmy Carter,
who is shown here posing for his 90th birthday,

And I thought, let's activate the innate immune system
because the innate immune system is our first line

and it is upstream of adaptive immunity, namely T-cell.

what is the danger signal secreted by cancer cells

The second messenger, this beautiful molecule once made,
then activates a powerful downstream
effector protein called stimulator of interferon genes

STING activation then leads to production of interferon,
